prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In Physica A 564 (2021) 125498, L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. introduce a multi-layer network concept where each social layer represents a specific type of interaction. The nodes in the network are individuals, and the connections between them indicate social contacts that could potentially lead to infection, with the strength of the connection represented by a probability value between 0 and 1. The first layer, focusing on home interactions, is made up of groups of varying sizes with internal connections but no external links, essentially starting as disconnected components that reflect different families. The authors base the group compositions on the distribution of family sizes in Argentina in 2009, with probabilities assigned to family sizes ranging from 1 to 10 members. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of the population in any country engages in work or economic activities that involve interacting with others, making work a crucial aspect of social relationships, especially during an epidemic. To represent work activity, we propose a general layer connecting individuals aged 18 to 59, comprising 60% of Argentina's population. Due to the diverse jobs and companies, creating a precise connection rule reflecting the real-world is challenging. We consider a scenario with randomly sized groups ranging from 5 to 30 individuals, interconnected similarly to the "home" layer, as shown in Fig. 2(b) with n = 100. The spread of the virus among group nodes depends on edge weights, detailed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation plays a vital role in most cities but poses a risk for epidemic spread due to high congestion and movement of vehicles. Our third layer represents public transport users, accounting for 50% of the population on average, with group sizes ranging from 10 to 40 individuals. This layer aims to capture the dynamics of city transportation, considering factors like daily usage times and varying percentages in different city sizes.
original_pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 Fig. 2. Each social layer of the proposed multi-layer network. The nodes are people and do not change across layers, and the weighted connections represent social contact which may lead to infection according to the edge weight (probability value within [0, 1)). The first layer represents home interactions and is composed of a set of groups with varying sizes, which are fully connected internally. These groups have no external connections, i.e., the network starts with disconnected components representing each family. To create each group, we consider the Brazilian family size distribution for 2010 [22], the year with more detailed information on family sizes from 1 up to 14 members. We consider the probability of a family having sizes from 1 to 10. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
original_post_context: . A large fraction of the population in any country need to work or practice some kind of economic activity, which means interacting with other people. Thus, work represents one of the most important factors of social relations, which is also very important in an epidemic scenario. To represent the work activity, we propose a generic layer to connect people with ages from 18 to 59 years, i.e., 60% of the total population in the case of Brazil. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using n = 100. Although the nodes of a group are fully connected, the transmission of the virus depends directly on the edge weights, which we discuss in-depth on Section 3.1.1. Collective transports are essential in most cities but are among the most crowded environments and play an important role in an epidemic scenario due to the possibility of geographical spread, as vehicles are constantly moving around. The third layer we propose represents these public transports that include people who do not possess or use a personal vehicle. In Brazil the number of people using public transport depends on the size of the city, with 64.98% in the capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], with an average use of around 1.2 h a day.1 Here we consider the average of the population between the two cases (50%), randomly sampled, to participate in the ''transports'' layer. Random groups are created with sizes between [10, 40], uniformly sampled, and the nodes within each group are fully connected. This variation of sizes 1 http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-brasil/noticia/2015/02/brasileiros-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html. 5

prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A in 2021, Scabini and colleagues introduced a multi-layer network model representing social interactions. Each layer of the network focused on a specific type of interaction, with the first layer representing home interactions based on Argentine family size distribution. The network started with disconnected components representing individual families, with each family size following the distribution of sizes ranging from 1 to 10 members. The structure of this layer ensured that each family had at least one adult. Additionally, a second layer representing work interactions was proposed to connect people aged 18 to 59 years, comprising 60% of the total population in Argentina. This layer aimed to capture the important role of work in social relations, especially in the context of an epidemic scenario. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: . In Section 3.1.1, we delve into the importance of edge weights in determining the transmission of the virus among fully connected nodes within a group. Collective transportation, a vital aspect of urban life, presents a high risk for spreading epidemics due to its crowded nature and constant movement of vehicles. Our proposed third layer focuses on public transport, catering to individuals without access to a personal vehicle. In Argentina, public transport usage varies depending on the city size, with approximately 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other areas [23], averaging 1.2 hours daily. We include 50% of the population in our model, randomly divided into groups of 10 to 40 members, each group being fully interconnected.

The nodes are people and do not change across layers, and the weighted connections represent social contact which may lead to infection according to the edge weight (probability value within [0, 1)). The first layer represents home interactions and is composed of a set of groups with varying sizes, which are fully connected internally. These groups have no external connections, i.e., the network starts with disconnected components representing each family. To create each group, we consider the Brazilian family size distribution for 2010 [22], the year with more detailed information on family sizes from 1 up to 14 members. We consider the probability of a family having sizes from 1 to 10. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In their study published in Physica A 564 (2021), eiva et al. explored the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in the number of cases, deaths, and hospitalizations. The researchers initiated the spread of the virus in a social network by infecting a node with a degree closest to the average network degree, with subsequent propagation occurring over daily iterations for up to 300 days. The study considered an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the start, resulting in an initial infection probability of β < 1, symbolizing natural social distancing practices and precautions. The researchers noted that this initial value of β produced outcomes more closely aligned with the Argentinian pandemic data. After 27 days, a moderate quarantine was implemented to simulate the measures adopted by many Argentinian states, such as Buenos Aires. During this quarantine, certain layers of the social network were removed or had reduced contact rates, with an effective β value of 0.09. Essential services and activities with elevated precautionary measures continued, despite the quarantine. The study assessed how different β values affected the epidemic curve, with higher values leading to faster disease spread and increased cases and deaths, countered by natural immunization among recovered individuals, which hastened the end of the epidemic.

Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentinian epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context:
causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model shows a notable overall similarity within its standard deviation. The significant difference in the number of diagnosed cases in the past ten days may be due to the increased testing in Argentina or the consistent decrease in isolation levels in the country (below 50% for most days of the past month). We assumed a fixed isolation level based on the early days after government decrees in Argentina, but data suggests these levels are fluctuating. As a result, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in future simulations may be higher than reported in this paper. The average daily death toll in the proposed models is higher than official numbers, possibly due to higher underdetection rates and fewer tests being conducted. An analysis of death numbers in Argentina from January to April indicates a significant increase starting from February 26, the day of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in Argentina, suggesting the actual death toll may be much higher than reported.

Looking ahead, after the initial epidemic phase, four possible actions can be considered after 90 days (May 26): a) Maintain current isolation levels; b) Lift isolation measures and return to normal activities; c) Resume only work activities; or d) Increase isolation by halting work and transport activities.
original_pre_context: eiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 the effects of different actions on the overall epidemic picture, such as the increase and reduction of cases, deaths, and occupied beds in hospitals. The social network starts with all its layers and the original infection probabilities. The infection begins at a node with the closest degree to the average network degree and propagates at iterations of 1 day (up to 300 days). We consider an optimistic scenario in which people are aware of the virus since the beginning, thus the initial infection probability is β < 1. This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 24 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e., β = 0.09. The remaining activities on these layers represent services that could not be stopped, such as essential services, activities that are kept taking higher precautionary measures and disrespecting the quarantine. Under this scenario, we first analyze how the β parameter impacts the overall epidemic shape. Fig. 4(a) shows results for 4 β values in function of daily new cases and deaths, iterating from up to 300 days after the first infection. As higher the infection rates, faster is the disease spreading and the final number of cases and deaths. On the other hand, the epidemic ends faster due to natural immunization of recovered nodes. 4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Brazilian epidemic (up to May 18) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
original_post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model achieves a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The higher difference in the number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days may be related to the increase in Brazil's tests. Or yet, the constant decrease of isolation levels in the country (below 50% for most days of the past month) [43]. We considered here a fixed isolation level around what was observed in the first days after the government decrees in Brazil. Still, data from the same reference show that these levels are constantly changing. Therefore, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths for the remaining simulation may be higher than the reported on this paper (see the ''keep isolation'' scenario in the next section). Concerning the daily death toll, the average number of the proposed models is higher than that of the official numbers. This is somehow expected, considering that the underdetection rates may be higher in contrast to the fewer number of tests being performed. To better understand this, we analyzed the number of death in Brazil from January 1 to April 30, comparing cases between 2019 and 2020; the results are shown in Fig. 5. It is possible to observe a clear increasing pattern after February 26, which is the day of the first officially confirmed case of COVID-19 in Brazil, indicating that the real death toll may be significantly higher than the official numbers. 4.2. Future actions and its impacts After the initial epidemic phase, we consider four possible actions that can be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) Do nothing more, maintaining the current isolation levels; b) Stop isolation, returning activities to normal (initial network layers and weights); c) Return only work activities, restoring the initial probability of the layer; or d) Increase isolation, stopping the remaining activities in work and transport

post_context: ) for the first 83 days (up to May 17) to 4 different data sources of the Argentinian COVID-19 numbers: EU Open Data Portal (EUODP) [40], Worldometer [41], Johns Hopkins University [5], and World Health Organization (WHO) [42].The dashed lines indicate the standard deviation, with the average over a 5-day period shown by the curve and the solid lines representing the actual raw data. The higher average number of deaths predicted by the model could be due to underreporting (refer to Fig. 5). In Fig. 5, we analyze the impact of underreporting COVID-19 cases in Argentina by comparing death records from 2019 and 2020 for the same timeframe (January 1 to April 30) [44]. This total death difference is then compared to COVID-19 data from the WHO [42] and the Argentinian government [44], revealing a potentially significant underreporting of cases since the first confirmed case. By implementing a strict 90-day lockdown, the proposed model shows a significant decrease in infections and deaths compared to other scenarios, with a faster rate of recovery and lower overall numbers of cases and deaths. Peak cases are projected to occur around day 93 (June 1) and peak deaths around day 106 (June 11). By day 300, the estimated total diagnosed cases and deaths are 552,855 (± 195,802) and 87,059 (± 30,871) respectively. Utilizing the hospitalization timeframe outlined in Fig. 3, we can estimate the number of beds needed for regular and critical COVID-19 cases. Additionally, we analyze the cumulative growth of diagnosed and undiagnosed cases, as well as recoveries.

The dotted lines represent the standard deviation, and in the case of the real data, the curve is the average over a 5-day window, and the solid lines the real raw data. To understand the impact of the COVID-19 underdetection in Brazil, we considered the official death records of 2019 and 2020 at the same period (January 1 to April 30) [44]. Then the total death difference is compared to the COVID-19 records of the WHO [42] and the Brazilian government [44] data. The largest difference that appears right after the first confirmed case may indicate a significant underdetection of COVID-19 cases. returning all activities, considering the growth time, peak, and decay time. The final numbers in this case are 1,253,119 (± 26,009) diagnosed cases and 197,756 (± 5,693) deaths. If the isolation is strictly increased after 90 days (lockdown), the infection and death counts drop significantly compared to the other approaches. Moreover, the recovering time is much faster, as daily new cases stop earlier than the different scenarios. The peak of daily new cases happens around day 93 (June 1) and daily new deaths around day 106 (June 11). The total number of diagnosed cases and deaths after day 300 are 552,855 (± 195,802) and 87,059 (± 30,871). Considering the hospitalization time described in the scheme of Fig. 3, it is possible to estimate the number of occupied beds for regular hospitalization (severe cases) and ICU/Ventilation (critical cases). author: chunwei
pre_context:
In a recent study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva, et al., published in Physica A (2021), Figure 7 illustrates the total number of infected and recovered cases and the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three possible scenarios after 90 days (as of May 26). These scenarios include: (a) maintaining current isolation measures with limited activities such as no schools and religious gatherings, reduced work, and limited public transportation; (b) ending isolation and returning schools, religious services, work, and public transportation to normal levels; or (c) increasing isolation measures by stopping work and public transportation.

Testing capacity is a significant limitation in accurately diagnosing cases, whether due to a low number of available tests or the rapid spread of the virus outpacing testing capabilities. As a result, the study assumes that only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases are being diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days from the first confirmed case, initial isolation measures were implemented which included the closure of schools and religious activities, while work and transport continued at 30% of the original capacity (achieved by further reducing the β term). After 90 days from the first case, different actions were considered: maintaining the current isolation levels, increasing isolation, ending isolation and returning all activities to 100%, or only returning work activities. Results indicate that maintaining current isolation levels will result in prolonged propagation, with an estimated peak around June 5, leading to an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths. By the end of the year, there could be 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths. Hospitals may exceed capacity around June 11, but with the efficient implementation of new ICU beds and proper patient logistics, the situation can still be managed. However, this optimistic assumption is based on social isolation levels remaining above 50%, as initially seen in the Argentine quarantine.
original_pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 Fig. 7. Total number of infected and recovered cases and evolution of hospital beds utilization in 3 possible scenarios after 90 days (May 26): (a) Keep isolation level (no schools and religion, reduced work and transports), (b) End isolation (return schools, religion, work and transports to normal) or (c) Increase isolation (stop work and public transports)). Testing is always limited, either by the low number of tests or the spreading velocity, which the testing procedure cannot keep up. We then considered that only hospitalization cases and 20% of the mild cases are diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
original_post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year. In this scenario, hospitals may exceed its maximum capacity around June 11. However, the efficient implementation of new ICU beds and proper logistic management of patients may still keep the situation under control. However, this is a very optimistic assumption, considering that our definition of ''keep isolation'' considers social isolation above 50% as registered at the beginning of the Brazilian quarantine [43]. author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), the researchers examined the potential outcomes of three different scenarios 90 days after the implementation of COVID-19 measures. The scenarios included maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. The study noted challenges in testing due to limitations in testing capacity and the rapid spread of the virus. The researchers assumed that only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases were being diagnosed, with asymptomatic cases not being diagnosed. The study also considered that mild cases would self-isolate at home if aware of their symptoms, while severe and critical cases would be hospitalized and isolated from social interactions.Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and
post_context: , and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year.Hospitals could potentially reach maximum capacity by June 11 in this situation. However, if new ICU beds are added efficiently and patient logistics are managed properly, the situation may still be manageable. It is important to note that our definition of "maintaining isolation" requires social isolation levels above 50%, as seen at the start of the Peruvian quarantine [43]. Peru's social isolation levels have consistently remained around 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A, researchers analyzed three scenarios for the evolution of COVID-19 cases after 90 days. The scenarios included maintaining current isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. Testing limitations were considered due to the low number of tests available or the rapid spread of the virus surpassing testing capabilities. Only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases were assumed to be diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases were not detected. Optimistic assumptions were made regarding infected individuals isolating themselves at home if they were aware of their symptoms, and severe or critical cases being hospitalized and removed from the network. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of
post_context: and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year. Hospitals could reach maximum capacity around June 11 in this situation. By efficiently adding new ICU beds and managing patients logistically, the situation may still be manageable. However, this is an optimistic view, as our definition of effective isolation requires social distancing levels above 50%, as seen at the start of the Colombian quarantine [43]. Colombia's current social isolation rates are consistently at 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), the authors examined three possible scenarios for the evolution of COVID-19 cases and hospital bed utilization after 90 days. These scenarios included maintaining current isolation measures, lifting isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. The study found that testing limitations due to the low number of tests or testing capabilities unable to keep up with the spreading velocity resulted in only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases being diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases were not diagnosed and continued to interact normally in the network. The study also assumed that mild cases, even when undiagnosed, would self-isolate at home if aware of their symptoms. Severe and critical cases would eventually be hospitalized and isolated from the network.Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of
post_context: (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year.In this situation, hospitals could reach their capacity limit by June 11. Despite this, if new ICU beds are quickly set up and patients are managed efficiently, the situation can still be managed. However, this outlook is very positive, as it assumes that social isolation levels remain above 50%, as was reported at the start of the Argentine quarantine period. Currently, social isolation levels in Argentina are consistently at 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), the authors analyze three possible scenarios after 90 days (May 26) in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic. These scenarios include: maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures and returning to normal activities, or increasing isolation measures. The study takes into account the limitations of testing in detecting cases, with only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases being diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and continue to spread within the network. The study also assumes that mild cases isolate themselves at home and that severe cases are hospitalized and isolated from the network. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and
post_context: until the end of the year. In this situation, hospitals could reach their full capacity by June 11. Yet, by adding new ICU beds and effectively managing patient logistics, the situation may still be manageable. This is an optimistic outlook, given that our measure of "effective isolation" requires a social isolation rate of over 50%, as seen at the start of the Argentinian quarantine. Currently, Argentina's social isolation rates are consistently at 12%.
